segment.source: You port your OpenGL Shader Language (GLSL) code to Microsoft High Level Shader Language (HLSL) code when you port your graphics architecture from OpenGL ES 2.0 to Direct3D 11 to create a game for Universal Windows Platform (UWP).
segment.target: You port your OpenGL Shader Language (GLSL) code to Microsoft High Level Shader Language (HLSL) code when you port your graphics architecture from OpenGL ES 2.0 to Direct3D 11 to create a game for Universal Windows Platform (UWP).

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: You port your OpenGL Shader Language (GLSL) code to Microsoft High Level Shader Language (HLSL) code when you port your graphics architecture from OpenGL ES 2.0 to Direct3D 11 to create a game for Universal Windows Platform (UWP).
segment.target: You port your OpenGL Shader Language (GLSL) code to Microsoft High Level Shader Language (HLSL) code when you port your graphics architecture from OpenGL ES 2.0 to Direct3D 11 to create a game for Universal Windows Platform (UWP).

segment.source: The GLSL that is referred to herein is compatible with OpenGL ES 2.0; the HLSL is compatible with Direct3D 11.
segment.target: The GLSL that is referred to herein is compatible with OpenGL ES 2.0; the HLSL is compatible with Direct3D 11.

segment.source: For info about the differences between Direct3D 11 and previous versions of Direct3D, see Feature mapping.
segment.target: For info about the differences between Direct3D 11 and previous versions of Direct3D, see Feature mapping.

segment.source: Porting GLSL pre-defined global variables to HLSL
segment.target: Porting GLSL pre-defined global variables to HLSL

segment.source: Examples of porting GLSL variables to HLSL
segment.target: Examples of porting GLSL variables to HLSL

segment.source: Uniform, attribute, and varying in GLSL
segment.target: Uniform, attribute, and varying in GLSL

segment.source: Constant buffers and data transfers in HLSL
segment.target: Constant buffers and data transfers in HLSL

segment.source: Examples of porting OpenGL rendering code to Direct3D
segment.target: Examples of porting OpenGL rendering code to Direct3D

segment.source: OpenGL ES 2.0 and Direct3D 11 have many similarities.
segment.target: OpenGL ES 2.0 and Direct3D 11 have many similarities.

segment.source: They both have similar rendering pipelines and graphics features.
segment.target: They both have similar rendering pipelines and graphics features.

segment.source: But Direct3D 11 is a rendering implementation and API, not a specification; OpenGL ES 2.0 is a rendering specification and API, not an implementation.
segment.target: But Direct3D 11 is a rendering implementation and API, not a specification; OpenGL ES 2.0 is a rendering specification and API, not an implementation.

segment.source: Direct3D 11 and OpenGL ES 2.0 generally differ in these ways:
segment.target: Direct3D 11 and OpenGL ES 2.0 generally differ in these ways:

segment.source: Hardware and operating system agnostic specification with vendor provided implementations
segment.target: Hardware and operating system agnostic specification with vendor provided implementations

segment.source: Microsoft implementation of hardware abstraction and certification on Windows platforms
segment.target: Microsoft implementation of hardware abstraction and certification on Windows platforms

segment.source: Abstracted for hardware diversity, runtime manages most resources
segment.target: Abstracted for hardware diversity, runtime manages most resources

segment.source: Direct access to hardware layout; app can manage resources and processing
segment.target: Direct access to hardware layout; app can manage resources and processing

segment.source: Provides higher-level modules via third-party libraries (for example, Simple DirectMedia Layer (SDL))
segment.target: Provides higher-level modules via third-party libraries (for example, Simple DirectMedia Layer (SDL))

segment.source: Higher-level modules, like Direct2D, are built upon lower modules to simplify development for Windows apps
segment.target: Higher-level modules, like Direct2D, are built upon lower modules to simplify development for Windows apps

segment.source: Microsoft adds optional features to the API in a generic way so they aren't specific to any particular hardware vendor
segment.target: Microsoft adds optional features to the API in a generic way so they aren't specific to any particular hardware vendor

segment.source: GLSL and HLSL generally differ in these ways:
segment.target: GLSL and HLSL generally differ in these ways:

segment.source: Shader compilation integrated into the graphics API
segment.target: Shader compilation integrated into the graphics API

segment.source: The HLSL compiler compiles the shader to an intermediate binary representation before Direct3D passes it to the driver.
segment.target: The HLSL compiler compiles the shader to an intermediate binary representation before Direct3D passes it to the driver.

segment.source: Note This binary representation is hardware independent.
segment.target: Note This binary representation is hardware independent.

segment.source: It's typically compiled at app build time, rather than at app run time.
segment.target: It's typically compiled at app build time, rather than at app run time.

segment.source: Constant buffers and data transfers via input layout declarations
segment.target: Constant buffers and data transfers via input layout declarations

segment.source: Note Use the row_major type-modifier to change the layout for one variable.
segment.target: Note Use the row_major type-modifier to change the layout for one variable.

segment.source: For more info, see Variable Syntax.
segment.target: For more info, see Variable Syntax.

segment.source: You can also specify a compiler flag or a pragma to change the global default.
segment.target: You can also specify a compiler flag or a pragma to change the global default.

segment.source: Note HLSL has textures and samplers as two separate objects.
segment.target: Note HLSL has textures and samplers as two separate objects.

segment.source: In GLSL, like Direct3D 9, the texture binding is part of the sampler state.
segment.target: In GLSL, like Direct3D 9, the texture binding is part of the sampler state.

segment.source: In GLSL, you present much of the OpenGL state as pre-defined global variables.
segment.target: In GLSL, you present much of the OpenGL state as pre-defined global variables.

segment.source: For example, with GLSL, you use the gl\_Position variable to specify vertex position and the gl\_FragColor variable to specify fragment color.
segment.target: For example, with GLSL, you use the gl\_Position variable to specify vertex position and the gl\_FragColor variable to specify fragment color.

segment.source: In HLSL, you pass Direct3D state explicitly from the app code to the shader.
segment.target: In HLSL, you pass Direct3D state explicitly from the app code to the shader.

segment.source: For example, with Direct3D and HLSL, the input to the vertex shader must match the data format in the vertex buffer, and the structure of a constant buffer in the app code must match the structure of a constant buffer (cbuffer) in shader code.
segment.target: For example, with Direct3D and HLSL, the input to the vertex shader must match the data format in the vertex buffer, and the structure of a constant buffer in the app code must match the structure of a constant buffer (cbuffer) in shader code.

segment.source: In GLSL, you apply modifiers (qualifiers) to a global shader variable declaration to give that variable a specific behavior in your shaders.
segment.target: In GLSL, you apply modifiers (qualifiers) to a global shader variable declaration to give that variable a specific behavior in your shaders.

segment.source: In HLSL, you don’t need these modifiers because you define the flow of the shader with the arguments that you pass to your shader and that you return from your shader.
segment.target: In HLSL, you don’t need these modifiers because you define the flow of the shader with the arguments that you pass to your shader and that you return from your shader.

segment.source: You pass a uniform variable from the app code into either or both vertex and fragment shaders.
segment.target: You pass a uniform variable from the app code into either or both vertex and fragment shaders.

segment.source: You must set the values of all uniforms before you draw any triangles with those shaders so their values stay the same throughout the drawing of a triangle mesh.
segment.target: You must set the values of all uniforms before you draw any triangles with those shaders so their values stay the same throughout the drawing of a triangle mesh.

segment.source: Some uniforms are set for the entire frame and others uniquely to one particular vertex-pixel shader pair.
segment.target: Some uniforms are set for the entire frame and others uniquely to one particular vertex-pixel shader pair.

segment.source: See How to: Create a Constant Buffer and Shader Constants.
segment.target: See How to: Create a Constant Buffer and Shader Constants.

segment.source: You initialize a varying variable inside the vertex shader and pass it through to an identically named varying variable in the fragment shader.
segment.target: You initialize a varying variable inside the vertex shader and pass it through to an identically named varying variable in the fragment shader.

segment.source: Because the vertex shader only sets the value of the varying variables at each vertex, the rasterizer interpolates those values (in a perspective-correct manner) to generate per fragment values to pass into the fragment shader.
segment.target: Because the vertex shader only sets the value of the varying variables at each vertex, the rasterizer interpolates those values (in a perspective-correct manner) to generate per fragment values to pass into the fragment shader.

segment.source: These variables vary across each triangle.
segment.target: These variables vary across each triangle.

segment.source: Use the structure that you return from your vertex shader as the input to your pixel shader.
segment.target: Use the structure that you return from your vertex shader as the input to your pixel shader.

segment.source: Make sure the semantic values match.
segment.target: Make sure the semantic values match.

segment.source: An attribute is a part of the description of a vertex that you pass from the app code to the vertex shader alone.
segment.target: An attribute is a part of the description of a vertex that you pass from the app code to the vertex shader alone.

segment.source: Unlike a uniform, you set each attribute’s value for each vertex, which, in turn, allows each vertex to have a different value.
segment.target: Unlike a uniform, you set each attribute’s value for each vertex, which, in turn, allows each vertex to have a different value.

segment.source: Define a vertex buffer in your Direct3D app code and match it to the vertex input defined in the vertex shader.
segment.target: Define a vertex buffer in your Direct3D app code and match it to the vertex input defined in the vertex shader.

segment.source: See How to: Create a Vertex Buffer and How to: Create an Index Buffer.
segment.target: See How to: Create a Vertex Buffer and How to: Create an Index Buffer.

segment.source: Create an input layout in your Direct3D app code and match semantic values with those in the vertex input.
segment.target: Create an input layout in your Direct3D app code and match semantic values with those in the vertex input.

segment.source: Constants that are compiled into the shader and never change.
segment.target: Constants that are compiled into the shader and never change.

segment.source: static means the value isn't exposed to constant buffers, const means the shader can't change the value.
segment.target: static means the value isn't exposed to constant buffers, const means the shader can't change the value.

segment.source: So, the value is known at compile time based on its initializer.
segment.target: So, the value is known at compile time based on its initializer.

segment.source: In GLSL, variables without modifiers are just ordinary global variables that are private to each shader.
segment.target: In GLSL, variables without modifiers are just ordinary global variables that are private to each shader.

segment.source: When you pass data to textures (Texture2D in HLSL) and their associated samplers (SamplerState in HLSL), you typically declare them as global variables in the pixel shader.
segment.target: When you pass data to textures (Texture2D in HLSL) and their associated samplers (SamplerState in HLSL), you typically declare them as global variables in the pixel shader.

segment.source: Use this table to port your GLSL types to HLSL.
segment.target: Use this table to port your GLSL types to HLSL.

segment.source: For more info, see Scalar Types.
segment.target: For more info, see Scalar Types.

segment.source: signed integer vector: ivec2, ivec3, ivec4
segment.target: signed integer vector: ivec2, ivec3, ivec4

segment.source: These types also have vector expansions similar to float, bool, and int:
segment.target: These types also have vector expansions similar to float, bool, and int:

segment.source: For more info, see Vector Type and Keywords.
segment.target: For more info, see Vector Type and Keywords.

segment.source: vector is also type defined as float4 (typedef vector float, 4 vector;).
segment.target: vector is also type defined as float4 (typedef vector float, 4 vector;).

segment.source: For more info, see User-Defined Type.
segment.target: For more info, see User-Defined Type.

segment.source: also, float1x1, float1x2, float1x3, float1x4, float2x1, float2x3, float2x4, float3x1, float3x2, float3x4, float4x1, float4x2, float4x3
segment.target: also, float1x1, float1x2, float1x3, float1x4, float2x1, float2x3, float2x4, float3x1, float3x2, float3x4, float4x1, float4x2, float4x3

segment.source: These types also have matrix expansions similar to float:
segment.target: These types also have matrix expansions similar to float:

segment.source: You can also use the matrix type to define a matrix.
segment.target: You can also use the matrix type to define a matrix.

segment.source: matrix is also type defined as float4x4 (typedef matrix float, 4, 4 matrix;).
segment.target: matrix is also type defined as float4x4 (typedef matrix float, 4, 4 matrix;).

segment.source: For more info, see User-Defined Type.
segment.target: For more info, see User-Defined Type.

segment.source: precision qualifiers for float, int, sampler
segment.target: precision qualifiers for float, int, sampler

segment.source: This qualifier provides minimum precision requirements that are greater than that provided by min16float and less than a full 32-bit float.
segment.target: This qualifier provides minimum precision requirements that are greater than that provided by min16float and less than a full 32-bit float.

segment.source: This qualifier applied to float and int is equivalent to min16float and min12int in HLSL.
segment.target: This qualifier applied to float and int is equivalent to min16float and min12int in HLSL.

segment.source: Minimum 10 bits of mantissa, not like min10float.
segment.target: Minimum 10 bits of mantissa, not like min10float.

segment.source: This qualifier applied to float provides a floating point range of -2 to 2.
segment.target: This qualifier applied to float provides a floating point range of -2 to 2.

segment.source: Minimum fixed-point signed 2.8 bit value (2 bits of whole number and 8 bits fractional component).
segment.target: Minimum fixed-point signed 2.8 bit value (2 bits of whole number and 8 bits fractional component).

segment.source: The 8-bit fractional component can be inclusive of 1 instead of exclusive to give it the full inclusive range of -2 to 2.
segment.target: The 8-bit fractional component can be inclusive of 1 instead of exclusive to give it the full inclusive range of -2 to 2.

segment.source: This type is for 10Level9 (9_x feature levels) in which integers are represented by floating point numbers.
segment.target: This type is for 10Level9 (9_x feature levels) in which integers are represented by floating point numbers.

segment.source: This is the precision you can get when you emulate an integer with a 16-bit floating point number.
segment.target: This is the precision you can get when you emulate an integer with a 16-bit floating point number.

segment.source: For more info, see Scalar Types and Using HLSL minimum precision.
segment.target: For more info, see Scalar Types and Using HLSL minimum precision.

segment.source: Porting GLSL pre-defined global variables to HLSL
segment.target: Porting GLSL pre-defined global variables to HLSL

segment.source: Use this table to port GLSL pre-defined global variables to HLSL.
segment.target: Use this table to port GLSL pre-defined global variables to HLSL.

segment.source: No meaning unless you target Direct3D 9
segment.target: No meaning unless you target Direct3D 9

segment.source: Fragment color for color attachment n
segment.target: Fragment color for color attachment n

segment.source: Pixel shader output value that is stored in n render target, where 0 = n = 7.
segment.target: Pixel shader output value that is stored in n render target, where 0 = n = 7.

segment.source: Determines whether fragment belongs to a front-facing primitive.
segment.target: Determines whether fragment belongs to a front-facing primitive.

segment.source: Fragment position within a point (point rasterization only)
segment.target: Fragment position within a point (point rasterization only)

segment.source: The pixel or sample position in screen space
segment.target: The pixel or sample position in screen space

segment.source: You use semantics to specify position, color, and so on for vertex shader input and pixel shader input.
segment.target: You use semantics to specify position, color, and so on for vertex shader input and pixel shader input.

segment.source: You must match the semantics values in the input layout with the vertex shader input.
segment.target: You must match the semantics values in the input layout with the vertex shader input.

segment.source: For examples, see Examples of porting GLSL variables to HLSL.
segment.target: For examples, see Examples of porting GLSL variables to HLSL.

segment.source: For more info about the HLSL semantics, see Semantics.
segment.target: For more info about the HLSL semantics, see Semantics.

segment.source: Examples of porting GLSL variables to HLSL
segment.target: Examples of porting GLSL variables to HLSL

segment.source: Here we show examples of using GLSL variables in OpenGL/GLSL code and then the equivalent example in Direct3D/HLSL code.
segment.target: Here we show examples of using GLSL variables in OpenGL/GLSL code and then the equivalent example in Direct3D/HLSL code.

segment.source: Uniform, attribute, and varying in GLSL
segment.target: Uniform, attribute, and varying in GLSL

segment.source: Constant buffers and data transfers in HLSL
segment.target: Constant buffers and data transfers in HLSL

segment.source: Here is an example of how you pass data to the HLSL vertex shader that then flows through to the pixel shader.
segment.target: Here is an example of how you pass data to the HLSL vertex shader that then flows through to the pixel shader.

segment.source: In your app code, define a vertex and a constant buffer.
segment.target: In your app code, define a vertex and a constant buffer.

segment.source: Then, in your vertex shader code, define the constant buffer as a cbuffer and store the per-vertex data and the pixel shader input data.
segment.target: Then, in your vertex shader code, define the constant buffer as a cbuffer and store the per-vertex data and the pixel shader input data.

segment.source: Here we use structures called VertexShaderInput and PixelShaderInput.
segment.target: Here we use structures called VertexShaderInput and PixelShaderInput.

segment.source: Examples of porting OpenGL rendering code to Direct3D
segment.target: Examples of porting OpenGL rendering code to Direct3D

segment.source: Here we show an example of rendering in OpenGL ES 2.0 code and then the equivalent example in Direct3D 11 code.
segment.target: Here we show an example of rendering in OpenGL ES 2.0 code and then the equivalent example in Direct3D 11 code.

segment.source: Port from OpenGL ES 2.0 to Direct3D 11
segment.target: Port from OpenGL ES 2.0 to Direct3D 11
